availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

person.persName: Caleb Stinson (Kentucky Representative from Grayson County)

body.p: South Carolina-bornMarried to Lydia Ann Day. Father of Squire Stinson, Charles W. Stinson, Harriet Stinson Wilson, Amos Stinson, Lydia A. Stinson House, William J. Stinson, Austin Stinson, American Ann Stinson Crawford, and Debbie Stinson. Served as a founding commissioner for the Caneyville and Cloverport Turnpike Road Company in 1860. Served as a Grayson County member of the Kentucky House of Representatives from 1863 to 1865. Assassinated by B. F. Dewees after giving a pro-amendment political speech in 1865.

bibl.p: Christopher Phillips, The Rivers Ran Backward: The Civil War and the Remaking of the American Middle Border (New York: Oxford University Press, 2016), 295-296; "An Act to Incorporate the Caneyville and Cloverport Turnpike Road Company," Acts of the General Assembly of the Commonwealth of Kentucky, Passed, vol 2 (Frankfort: J. B. Major, State Printer, 1860), 289; Lewis Collins, Collins’ Historical Sketches of Kentucky: History of Kentucky, vol. 2 (Collins & Company, 1878), 293; “Caleb Stinson,” (https://findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=23202291) (accessed March 3, 2017); Eighth Manuscript Census of the United States (1860), Population Schedules, Kentucky, Grayson County, p. 78; Eighth Manuscript Census of the United States (1860), Slave Schedules, Kentucky, Grayson County, p. 4.
